It was a very ethic number, Peruvian I venture to say, with little people sewed into it with yarn hair. It was fabulous so I had a good feeling about returning here. I convinced my coworker Bethany to follow me to this store after no luck at the previous one because, to quote the Black Eyed Peas, "I had a feeling." Not only did we each find perfect sweaters as well as one for our coworker Mirna -but Bethany happened upon the most ridiculous Lady Gaga inspired blouse....it's epic. I cannot wait to make my friend Sarah Jayne pee in her pants when she sees me in this blouse! Another successful trip to Village Discount Outlet. Special shout out to worker Cathy who should have her own reality show. She has worked there for 25 years and had a wit so sharp she almost cut my tags off with her sarcasm. She was a delight and truly hilarious as we checked out!

17.description: I hadn't been here in quite some time and thought I would stop in today.It seemed cleaner and neater than the last time I was here, and did not smell as musty.But seriously, who hangs pants like that? Both clips on on leg, and everything hanging at a diagonal? Weird and very hard to shop that way.

10.description: This one has been a clusterf*** for years and it seems as if nothing has changed. Nothing is ever sorted so you really really really have to be in  the mood to dig. I always am so it never affects my shopping. Today I got some good finds. A Gwen Stefani brand LAMB bag for 7 bucks, a Brighton black bag from the 1980s that I will sell for about 8 times what I paid for it. Another pair of Nunn Bush men's shoes that are wonderful and will also pay for themselves.As with any thrift store, some crap, mostly crap. Keep on pushing to find that gem. Look on the floor. Look in every aisle. The seasoned thrifters often hide good stuff in random places so they can come back for it on half price day. Beat them to the punch....look through everything!

11.description: The Village Discount has been my favorite place in chicago to shop, But this one is only good for certain things...1. It's great for a clothes, i found a dior blazer here 2 vintage gucci bags and 2 pairs of coach shoes. and a Longchamp bag - ( i know my designers and how to prove if real or not so i always ask to see before purchase). 2. They have a good amount of FAKE designer handbags they charge to much for.3. I don't care for the staff half the time. Andy the guy who seems to be the manager is rude half the time, and that cathy lady needs to shave her mustache and stop being rude to the customers.4. They need to clean up that section with the toys and electronics and organize it better and make it easier to move through. 5. It's great for Records -they have decent selection- . They have a decent Jewelry/Book Section The clothes section is decent for blazers/ coats/shoes 7. They don't have furniture really- they just disappoint there.I enjoy the half off sales- everything is mega cheap!  I've gotten some great finds here. I like it but it surely needs improvement but its right by the train which makes it easy to access.

26.description: If you think this store deserves three stars, you don't go to a lot of thrift stores.  One of the worst Villages in Chicago, this store, unlike other huge Village Discounts, doesn't even have a second floor furniture room.  The front part of the store is populated by eBay "hawks" hounding the overworked staff over porcelain figurines in the display cabinet, the rest of the store is so cramped you can't fit a person and a stroller through the clothing aisles... and there are plenty of strollers.  I love thrift stores, I live for them, I have furnished my house with thrift store merchandise, and yet I have not once found something worthwhile at this particular Village.  (Okay, that's not 100% true, I have scored some cute plastic costume jewelry.)  I am writing this review as a service to those who value thrifting and prefer a keener eye: if you really want to get your hands dirty while listening to Jon Secada deep cuts, shop here.  If you want more quality, better-organized merchandise, furniture or housewares that aren't dirty and broken, look elsewhere.

27.description: I love thrifting. At this VD Neva found a great wool blazer that really makes her look like a proper professor! I don't think I found anything here, but it wasn't because there wasn't anything good. Things are way orderly here too, so it is easy to maneuver this store. The music they were playing was awful, but it is a thrift store so it's usually something terrible. I remember the song that really got me was "butterfly kisses" ya know the one where the guy's daughter is getting married and she has daisies "all up in her hair" yuck that song makes me want to vomit.

35.description: I was really shocked at how many great pairs of like new shoes I found here. Where else can you find a pair of the ultimate gold sequin stilettos in your size for $1.50? I also scored a pair of pointy toed red BCBG flats with the price tags still attached for $2. Oh and whoever stashed the pair of Dolce Pumps in the prom dresses, THANK YOU. I just scored them for a $1.35! HELL YEAH!There are definitely deals to be had here, but don't think you're just going to find things by skimming through the racks, you have to dig! ALSO...This place does has far more creepy dudes then some of the other locations, but it is safe to come here if you're a girl.

8.description: It is right in my neighborhood but I do not have it on my normal shopping trail because it is such a mess.  This store is chaos from start to finish. The parking lot spaces are narrow and parking can be a challenge on sale days.  The aisles are also too close together and over stuffed with merchandise so navigating the store is a challenge, especially on busy sale weekends. It is also a bit dirty and smells funny-like some of the customers.  There are always people coughing and you can't help but feel like it is a great place for some Stephen Kind worthy pandemic to break out.  I would never let my children set foot in this place for fear of catching some horrible virus.  I use hand sanitizer when I get back to the car and wash my hands the second I get home.  But despite all of these things I still shop there.  Every once in awhile I will brave it all for a quick run through on the big half price days.  I almost always find some high quality kids clothes for a good price.  The selection isn't huge for the kids stuff so you can scan through it fairly quick.Yes, the check out lanes are slow. But the crabby lady that people mention-she is always nice to me.  One time I really wanted a Tow Mater shirt for my son and it didn't have a tag so I just threw it in with the rest and would see what happened.  The clerks on Elston or Clark would totally have snagged it and not let me purchase it.  But this woman just charged me .40 and moved on!  Yay!

0.description: Favorite place in Chicago. Half off days are cool. Regular half off days are cool too. Then there are the various sales during the week like 2 for $1 DVDs after the big sales or two for Tuesday and so on.. Yea everyone's complaint about the rude cashier in the mornings. We'll call her A". A is usually off by 4 that's when the morning shift ends. But there's someone worts than "A".. I'm talking of course about the security guard there.. Just awful. The worst. She talks loudly on the phone, which is ok to know when she's coming around and you can just avoid her all along. But then there are those days when she wants everyone to know her business. Like telling a random customer how other customers like to complain about her. This is so everyone in the store can hear her. I go on her days off btw. Lol. The older lady is the best all you have to do is call her by her name and she'll take care of you. Remember she WANTS you to take this sh*t cause it is better than having to rack it. She's really bringing profit to the store along with the girls that work the evening shift that's when I see them.

38.description: Okay, so here's the scoop on this place... Point #1   The people that work and shop here are wierdos. That's it. Plain and simple. It is just a gathering mass of wierdos scavenging the place and it's mass chaos.point #2    No body here speaks english. There's one mean old lady (cashier) that speaks english, and she's scary and horrible.point #3    The guys that go here to shop are on the prowl for their next yucky victim. Unless you're also on the prowl for a toothless mexican guy, watch out, and if you're a girl, don't go here alone.Now the good part:point #1    They have clothes (sometimes really nice stuff) REALLY cheap here. point #2    most of the people who shop here wouldn't know Armani if they were strangled with their silk scarves, so there is a chance you'll find some awesome stuff.That's it. Plain and simple.

20.description: I've only been to the Lawrence Ave. site, and my comments would be similar to many others--great bargains to be found under conditions of somewhat-controlled chaos.  But that's what makes finding them fun!  I don't run in here for 10 min., because I need longer than 10 min. to discover real finds, but a half-hour stop on the way home from work usually has me leaving with a bag of clothing, and even though there don't seem to be dressing rooms (at least, not anywhere obvious), most of the time things fit, and the rest of the time I can easily find tiny people the rest will fit.  One observation:  While the signs say they accept credit cards, I've never had them actually accept mine . . . they negotiate for cash or check instead.

19.description: It smells like someone hid dirty diapers Easter egg style throughout this place. I go through these periods once in a while, let's call it...broke! And I think, "hey, I should try thrift shopping!" It only took me about 10 minutes to figure out that I am physically unable to purchase used clothing from this place...and yes, I realize I sound like a priss, feel free to throw hate in my direction v_vBut! They do have a good size book selection and they're like $0.40 each! Lot's of high school required reading and romance novels, but I found some older popular paperbacks in good shape.

33.description: If you're looking for lively conversation about your weekend plans (in English), check out Trader Joe's (I do whenever I'm lonely), but if you'd like a thrift store jam-packed with men's and women's duds of all kinds, this is your place.  It's a great way to waste away a day. Since I live nearby, I tend to go on weekdays when I can beat the crowds and putz around a bit. They've got tons of men's pants and dress shirts and whenever I've shopped with a woman, she's walked off with some very cute items. Although I tend not to do thrift shoes, they have lots. I like the smaller, cozier Kedzie Ave. location just as much.

2.description: Señor Don says that they will open a new register if there are three or more people in line. What if there are more than three people in each of two lines? That's how it was today and I left my stuff on the counter and left after waiting 10 minutes. They seem to always be understaffed here. The cashier has to run the register, clean up, check bags, and show people items behind the counter. Don't bother checking your bag, I usually breeze through with it because you have to stand around and wait to check it, even when someone is behind the counter! And you'll have to wait again to pick it up. They do have some good stuff here occasionally, but you'll have to dig hard to find it and if something is behind the counter, it's probably not worth waiting around to see it because the price will be off the charts. They have two vintage trumpets there behind the counter now that were first marked $3000, they dropped them to $1500 the next month. They are at $350 now and still not selling.I believe the under staffing effects their sales. If they had someone behind the counter all the time, they'd sell more because people could actually see the stuff that's behind the counter. I usually don't bother because I know it will be a long wait.Another thing I have noticed is if you do stand at the counter, no employee will ever ask you if you'd like to see anything. I mean NEVER. They walk around with their eyes averted and you practically have to grab them by the collar to get them to show you an item!

34.description: Yes, there are creepy dudes, you have to hunt for what you want, and it smells like a thrift store, but guys, you know what?  It IS a thrift store.  Those are like the requirements for being a thrift store.  I think places get turned down for not having enough creepy dudes perusing the racks. "Sorry, you do not meet the creep quota.  You have to be a Gap instead."Anyway, this store has had plenty of great stuff whenever I've gone and it's not too busy.

32.description: When I used to live around here six years ago, this was my favorite thrift. I would go twice a week and never leave empty handed. Those were the salad days, my friends!Now many years have passed, all the VDOs have raised their prices, and I honestly can't remember the last time I successfully found any treasure here. Two years ago? Maybe? Despite the fact that I never buy anything here anymore and the unspoken prerequisite that one must be marinating in one's own B.O. to enter, I still swing by every few months, because the place is so funny. Mainly because of the moustachioed female employee who's worked there as long as I've gone. What a Crabby Patty! She's always got something to say. The last time I went she found a dirty diaper hanging out in the middle of an aisle and screeched, "WHO LEFT THIS SHITTY DIAPER HERE? ANSWER ME! ANIMALS! YOU'RE ALL ANIMALS!"I never know how to rate thrift stores, because sometimes you make out like a bandit, sometimes you don't. I don't know, three stars?

18.description: So...my metaphorical Village Discount Outlet cherry has been undeniably popped; I have finally visited this one on Lawrence! I have been really trying to save money lately, and this place does make it ever so possible!I will let everyone know that all I bought there was clothing, and I was in a bit of a hurry, so I really wasn't looking around for anything else. But I was really pleasantly surprised at the variety of clothing at this place. I got a red Limited miniskirt, a REALLY cute Ann Taylor khaki shirt, a cute brown and white dress, and a halter dress...all for about $20!Everything is organized by color, so it will take some searching to find your size. And I didn't see any fitting rooms, but I am going to go out on a limb and assume that there are none, but with the prices they have, it's really not much of a gamble.The halter dress I picked up didn't end up working on me (sad...I know!) but it only cost $2.80, so I wasn't too upset.I saw someone mention the smell of this place. I noticed it too, but in all honesty (especially with it being summer and all) I expected nothing less.And the ladies who worked behind the register were old, angry at the manager, and paid more attention to each other than to me. But again, I expected nothing less.I was debating whether or not to give this place 3 or 4 stars. I ultimately decided 4 because, again, my expectations were not that high for this place. Plus...name brand skirts for about $7-10? That's definitely 4 star worthy in my book!

13.description: Cathy makes this store a three. If you're a regular here, or perchance get to encounter the snappy older woman you're in for a treat. She makes jokes, she clearly doesn't love her job, but she does it well. In fact, sometimes, I think she has a softer side, I've seen it- then again I treat her like a human being.Ex. I broke a sweet awesome unicorn mug for the SO, well the handle, but it was a clean break, I still wanted it because I knew I could do something with it, she charged me 10 cents. SWEET.Now on to the store. It's more a solid 2, they get 1 for Cathy. I say 3 because the front corner is a disaster, not in that i'm a snob and don't get thrift stores kind of way, but in a wtf who the hell is okay w/that fire hazard pile of shit kind of way. It's not safe and never cleaned up, ever. I've been there enough to say so.So the goods, I get all kinds of tacky fabrics there +Shoes, I've scored a few decent Macy's quality brands there with tags on the bottoms still +Fostoria, twice now I've walked out with 1960s fostoria glass +Parking lot +Takes cards for over 5 dollars+Now, the bads...sadly, kind of out weigh the goods.It's more of a one find store -The clothing is in such disarray, which even for me says a lot. -Most of the housewares stuff is straight up junk, including frames -Most of the clothes are from shops around the area, which is cheaper quality than DOTS-It's good for me because I live near it, but I wouldn't say go out of your way for the place either. Everyone else there is somewhat to really rude -

4.description: This place is awful! Just tying not to step on the rat crap by the front door was probably more difficult then the Military trying to evade landmines in Vietnam. And I'm still unsure which odor is worse, the smell of the clothes of the donors who didn't use deodorant or the customers who have yet to discover it themselves.

24.description: This Village is smelly and messy and I love it! Yeah, you have to dig through stuff sometimes... and ok, watch out for the employees, they will run you over with a clothes rack... but I have scored many great apartment items here. Especially random pieces of fabric. Also books, lots of books. It is harder to find clothes here because everything is packed in very tightly (as it is at most Village stores). But if you have the time to spare and are willing to dig a bit, your efforts will usually be rewarded.

6.description: Rude Rosy should be the new name of this place. Yes, I used to be a big fan of this Village. But the attitudes and rudeness get me everything time. I had already hit up my fave location on Clark already this week, still needed so more glassware for a project. So walked in. Everything disarray for the most part. But I found what I needed. But its the register I dread most. Both cashiers who work here usually rude, with the older lady being very vocal with hers around the store. She is bad and I now walk out whenever she is there. Today, I got the mid age lady who got an attitude when I asked for an addition paper bag for my glass items to line them. She had put my items in the bag with other class item's break. Great. I had to ask for paper and do it myself after the sale. I give this store 3 stars due to the great items you find. I have found Vera Wang here before in great condition. But the cashiers and disarray of the store turns me off. I say thrift at a different Villiage if I were you.

22.description: So...my metaphorical Village Discount Outlet cherry has been undeniably popped; I have finally visited this one on Lawrence! I have been really trying to save money lately, and this place does make it ever so possible!I will let everyone know that all I bought there was clothing, and I was in a bit of a hurry, so I really wasn't looking around for anything else. But I was really pleasantly surprised at the variety of clothing at this place. I got a red Limited miniskirt, a REALLY cute Ann Taylor khaki shirt, a cute brown and white dress, and a halter dress...all for about $20!Everything is organized by color, so it will take some searching to find your size. And I didn't see any fitting rooms, but I am going to go out on a limb and assume that there are none, but with the prices they have, it's really not much of a gamble.The halter dress I picked up didn't end up working on me (sad...I know!) but it only cost $2.80, so I wasn't too upset.I saw someone mention the smell of this place. I noticed it too, but in all honesty (especially with it being summer and all) I expected nothing less.And the ladies who worked behind the register were old, angry at the manager, and paid more attention to each other than to me. But again, I expected nothing less.I was debating whether or not to give this place 3 or 4 stars. I ultimately decided 4 because, again, my expectations were not that high for this place. Plus...name brand skirts for about $7-10? That's definitely 4 star worthy in my book!

15.description: On a good day you can find some great stuff, but that is the only plus. There is one woman who works there that is extremely rude and the place is always a mess. I have been to other thrift stores and they are run better and more organized. I really can't stand the place.

40.description: Great thrift store. Large collection of clothing; you can find practically anything here. Lots of men's clothing which most places lack. I would give this place a 5 but I think it doesn't have enough non-clothing stuff.

7.description: If I could award this place with NO STARS, I would. I have shopped in this store since I went to high school in the neighborhood, 15 years ago. Every couple of years, I stop in and give it another chance. It has been the same every time, a huge disappointment.I don't care that this store is big, really big as far as thrift stores go, because it's dirty. It's not just dirty, it's also completely disorganized, stuff is everywhere, clothes are on the floor, etc.  Now, there isn't a fitting room in this store, which could be forgivable if the prices of the clothes weren't so high (high by thrift store standards). In fact, this is probably why there is SO MUCH STUFF, is because their prices are simply too high on a lot of items. Almost nine dollars for a no-name brand used black cotton dress that has light piling is a complete joke. even on half-off color days or special sales, is more than I would spend on that. Let's not neglect to mention the staff that works here. Over the years, I have always been treated like total crap by the employees. I have yet to encounter one that was not rude, mean or literally pushy (Yes, I have been physically pushed by them on more than one occasion as they try to walk past in an aisle. The best part is when they yell at you when they're doing it...). I feel sorry for you if you grabbed something that was missing a tag or if the tag fell off in your possession, because I've gotten yelled at (yes yelled at) for that too as they snatch the item out of your hand and tell you that you have to come back the next day for it.  Just don't expect them to set it aside for you. Oh no, you'll have to DIG through the entire store just to find it again. Good luck.My final complaint? They staple the price tag to the front of the garment with 2-3 staples. That means everything has holes in it from the staples. With there being many other thrift stores in this neighborhood, I advise you to save yourself the headache and skip this one. The one by montrose and kedzie has a changing room and the one on kedzie by irving is almost as big and much cleaner.Happy hunting.

36.description: Yes, it smells.  It's full of old stuff, what do you expect?  Yes, the staff is generally surly, and getting a smile out of them is like parting the Red Sea.  Hey, if I worked with the smell, I don't think I'd be too cheery either.Yes, there is a population of shiftless types who hang around the parking lot drinking, and sometimes wander in the store, and certainly harass any female who might wander into range.  I hate that, and have had to beat them off myself several times.  But, like others have said...there are some amazing finds to be had here, for practically nothing.  I've picked up like-new clothing, funky yarns, stemware, china, baskets, bags, hats, accessories, tchachkes, mugs, toys, shoes, luggage...at prices that are just ridiculous.  It does take time - I wouldn't go planning on spending less than an hour wading through stuff, but the rewards are definitely worth it.This is a thrift heavy area - there's another Village Thrift on Kedzie at Irving (about a mile away), and a Salvation Army about two blocks away at Montrose.  This is the biggest of the three and generally has the broadest selection - though for quality goods and better customer service, Sally's is the place.

30.description: I used to go here when I was younger in Albany Park. As with most thrift stores there are always gems to be found after hours of careful sifting. If you are on the lookout for something that you'll wear just once and will throw away later, then there's no reason not to stop here first. The highest priced clothes at Village Discount Outlet probably cost $20, and I still have a slick $3 port manteau that always garners compliments. With respect to books and music, you are better off going to a used book or record store for that sort of thing.

3.description: I don't know why this location has so many bad reviews. I just spent a good two hours today there doing some digging and I found a ton of clothes. Sure it's a little disorganized but it's because they have A LOT of stuff. This is a thrift store. At thrift stores, you have to really look. You can't expect to find something waiting for you as soon as you walk in. Go to a Forever 21 for that. I didn't encounter any rude employees like I've read about in some of the other reviews and there were also no long lines but keep in mind, I went during the early afternoon on a Friday. I wouldn't be surprised if it was more crowded on weekends. The employees don't bother you and pretty much just let you go about your business. However, some of the customers can learn the words 'Excuse me.' and 'Thank you.' Overall I'm glad I checked this location out after being horrified by reading some of the reviews. It's really not as bad as some people made it out to be. If you really take the time to dig, you'll find something there. I will definitely be coming back especially since it's so conveniently located by the Kimball brown line.

14.description: This place is HUUGEEE. Two floors. You can find ANYTHING. However, it is very messy and barely organized. Slightly smelly, but I've learned to endure thrift-store smells (It ain't that bad.)Cheap prices. There are discounts on items with tags of a certain color.Look hard, be determined, sift through the crap, and you may find some worthwhile items. For example, I went into the store determined to find a sweatshirt with my college emblazoned on it. I FOUND IT. Next-to brand new, as well! I've also found quite a few name-brand items, like Abercrombie and Fitch and Victoria's Secret PINK. Girls my age: try the little girls and boys sections. Some junior's clothes end up there.If you're patient, you may be rewarded here. Don't give up too quickly. If your arms get tired easily, then go do some push-ups. Then you can push the heavy hangers back and forth with no pain.

1.description: I have been searching for a barber that I can feel comfortable with and one that knows how to give excellent Haircuts. Frank is the man for the job! As you step into the shop you are greeted by Frank with a smile and a wave. The shop is clean and doesn't smell like hair or stale products, which is awesome! The shop reminds me of nicer times and is truly welcoming. There is even a bathroom you can use and a coat hanger section.As I waited there were plenty of news papers and magazines to read or I could watch the game on tv. When my turn was up Frank gave me a nice smile and waved me over. This was my first time having him cut my hair and I had not cut it in two months so I gave him a pretty big job lol. But he didn't complain he just smiled and looked at the pictures of the haircut I wanted, and a few moments later I had the haircut I wanted! My first time impressions of Frank is that he is a kind man and he is thoughtful when giving me my haircut. I can see why so many people go to him when they need a fresh cut. I will definitely be returning to Frank's barber shop. And if you are looking for an honest haircut from an honest man this is the spot to go to.

9.description: Frank gave me my first haircut 30 years ago, April 1981. My father has been getting his hair cut by Frank since 1976. For the exception of a few occasions, Frank has given me almost all of my hair cuts in my life. Only when I lived 400 miles away did other people cut my hair, even then I would try to get my hair cut when ever I was in Chicago. I have been back for 10 years, and Frank is the only person I trust with my hair. No one has ever come close to Frank. When you go to Frank it really feels like a true Barber shop, a place men can talk about sports, world events, movies, cars, and all the great things you get at the barber shop, a place for guys to be guys. To me, Frank is like family, and I strongly suggest if you are looking for a barber, look no further than Frank's Barber Shop. Over the years the neighborhood has changed, but one thing has stayed consistent, Frank's great personality and mastery of his craft. Thanks Frank for being not only the best Barber, but becoming a lifelong friend.

12.description: Got to say I am so pleased a friend sent me to see Frank.  My barber had retired and I searched desperately for 9 months for someone competent to cut my hair.Frank is a gentleman and a great barber.

21.description: The best barbershop haircut I've ever received, hands down. Frank is a treasure, and I almost don't want to submit a review so no one else finds out about him. Very relaxing and truly a great haircut (and you can't beat the hot lather shave!).

16.description: This IS your father's barber shop! The intersection of Montrose and Kedzie is the epicenter of the $5 haircut. They're everywhere! I decided to try some of these places since $5 is about what I spend on a pint at The Montrose Saloon. About the time I started getting the $5 haircut, I started hearing "hey, are you going bald?" "Why don't you try Rogain?" "What's up, old man!" Then I found Frank... When I saw the old fashion barber pole outside, I knew I had found the place! Mind you, the haircuts are over twice the other places in the neighborhood but Frank is a "barber" and not a "hair stylist". What's the difference? A barber is to a hair stylist as a violin is to a fiddle. It's the same thing executed differently. Frank is a kind man who has been cutting hair for around 50 years. He will remind you that he worked at a barber shop in the Music Box Theater building on Southport a long time ago. Recently he moved to his current location from across the street when a developer at his old location thought that this filthy urban intersection was the new Lincoln Park. I've seen a lot of people at Frank's since I've been going here. It's very popular w/ the police and fathers w/ their sons. However, I've never seen a woman in Frank's. This is a man's place! Of the many magazines on the table here, you won't see a Vogue or Us Magi zine, it's Car and Driver here. The haircuts are a lot more than just Frank using the clippers. He takes the time to deliver a quality haircut, finished w/ a hot Old Spice lather shave w/ a straight edged razor. If you are looking for a fantastic haircut, the way they used to be, then Frank is your guy! I get great haircuts here and no one has asked me if I'm going bald since!

17.description: I literally can't think of one point to criticize Frank's shop on. This is the real deal; I've dreaded the last month he's been out because of his hand. This man is also a Veteran. Thanks for everything, Frank!

10.description: Easily, without a doubt, the best haircuts I have ever gotten in my life. Frank has been doing this for 50 years, and he knows what he is doing! The atmosphere is great, a real boy's club. Frank is one of the nicest people in the world, and definitely one of the best barbers. If you want to step back in time for a REAL haircut, finished with a straight-razor, hot lather touch up, this is the place. Yes, it's more expensive than other places in the area, and I am always up for saving a few bucks, but Frank's work is worth every cent and more.

5.description: Frank is as skilled a barber as you're going to find, and he's a lovely guy to boot.  Just went in.  He had a guy in the chair and two ahead of me (not typical--usually one deep at worst, but he's going on vacation tomorrow).  One guy's cut was high and tight, short on top but parted.  Next guy: classic balding-guy baby mullet, like what you'd see in the dictionary next to "mullet, balding baby."  Next guy: semi-shag of grey hair.  Me:  buzz, 1 on the sides and 1.5 on top.  Every guy left with exactly what he wanted, looking better than when he came in.  Can't recommend him more highly.

11.description: This is a real barbershop, from the wood paneling to the fish trophies on the wall. Frank is very friendly. Like everyone else, I have to mention that he finishes up with a straight-razor clean-up.Also, the two times I've gotten a haircut there, I get TONS of compliments from people afterwards.

22.description: This IS your father's barber shop! The intersection of Montrose and Kedzie is the epicenter of the $5 haircut. They're everywhere! I decided to try some of these places since $5 is about what I spend on a pint at The Montrose Saloon. About the time I started getting the $5 haircut, I started hearing "hey, are you going bald?" "Why don't you try Rogain?" "What's up, old man!" Then I found Frank... When I saw the old fashion barber pole outside, I knew I had found the place! Mind you, the haircuts are over twice the other places in the neighborhood but Frank is a "barber" and not a "hair stylist". What's the difference? A barber is to a hair stylist as a violin is to a fiddle. It's the same thing executed differently. Frank is a kind man who has been cutting hair for around 50 years. He will remind you that he worked at a barber shop in the Music Box Theater building on Southport a long time ago. Recently he moved to his current location from across the street when a developer at his old location thought that this filthy urban intersection was the new Lincoln Park. I've seen a lot of people at Frank's since I've been going here. It's very popular w/ the police and fathers w/ their sons. However, I've never seen a woman in Frank's. This is a man's place! Of the many magazines on the table here, you won't see a Vogue or Us Magi zine, it's Car and Driver here. The haircuts are a lot more than just Frank using the clippers. He takes the time to deliver a quality haircut, finished w/ a hot Old Spice lather shave w/ a straight edged razor. If you are looking for a fantastic haircut, the way they used to be, then Frank is your guy! I get great haircuts here and no one has asked me if I'm going bald since!

0.description: Years ago, a taxi driver mentioned this place when he was driving me home from O'Hare and saw I lived close-by.  "Frank is the best!" He declared. "I moved away but I still come back." With that unsolicited endorsement, we brought our kids here that weekend.  We've been coming ever since.  Frank is, indeed, the best.  Thank you Flash Cab driver, wherever you are.

20.description: After 6 months, he is still the only barber I get my haircut at.

19.description: After 6 months, he is still the only barber I get my haircut at.

2.description: I discovered this place quite a few years ago when my regular barber was about to retire.  This a a great old time barber shop and one of the few places that know how to give a old fashioned flat top or crew cut.  Frank is a great guy and a real gentleman.  He just celebrated 50 years in the business.Frank is a Vietnam vet and many of his customers are retired or current members of law enforcement.

18.description: I'm happy to live a couple blocks from Frank's Barber Shop. Frank is a really nice guy who does a good and affordable job on hair. Just a classic, old-school, no-frills barber shop. A great place to have around.

13.description: Frank is very friendly and does a great men's hair cut!

4.description: I usually don't leave reviews, but Frank is the best and deserves a good review and my first review. He appreciates when someone leaves a review and I want him to know that we appreciate him and his skills by doing so. Frank is my new go to barber; I recommend him to anyone and everyone, one of those people is my cousin, who also loves this place.  I'm confident that he will get the job done no matter what style I bring to him and nail it. He doesn't make the experience of getting a haircut awkward; he always greets you when you walk in the shop, starts conversations while you're get your haircut, very friendly and I know his patrons love the environment he brings to the neighborhood, which is rare to see nowadays.

6.description: Ive lived close by to Franks for many years, but recently went in for the first time. I needed a haircut and my regular barber wasn't available.Over all, I had a great experience. Frank is very friendly, very skilled, and a pleasure to do business with. This is one of the old school barbershops that still remain true to tradition. Fresh clean cuts and hot shave cream straight razor clean up. This is a man's no bs kinds barbershop. Love it. Check him out.

15.description: Frank is the nicest guy in the world, and he gives great haircuts. He is a true throwback and a local treasure.

7.description: Frank is the only barber to consider on the north-side of Chicago!

8.description: This guy is the real deal...nice guy, he deserves your patronage.

3.description: You may not be able to cut down a tree or change the oil in your car, but you'll leave looking like a man.

14.description: He's been my Barber since 1989.-nuff said.

3.description: Primarily a shoe store, they also carry lingerie, all at relatively inexpensive prices.   Many of the shoes are the sort of thing that would look best with daring eveningwear or perhaps as part of an anime costume, but they also have flat insulated boots in the winter, regular "sensible shoes," and children's shoes.  The lingerie used to be less obvious, as was the store name (was New York Shoes), but now some of it is displayed above the shoe racks along the walls with more in the back of this small store, along with interesting panty hose and stockings.  Sort of a neighborhood Frederick's, but also with athletic shoes for toddlers!

1.description: This was just a waste of my time.  I'm so upset that I took the reviews for granted. Not sure why this store is named sexy girls.  So sad.

2.description: I've ventured into this store about five times in the last two weeks and I a have to say, I was misled by the title of the store.First there was the initial sexiness, the long shiny high-heeled boots in every color.   There were red.. Even purple. ok.  But "Sexy Girls of the Hollywood" really promised more than they could deliver.  There wasn't enough sexy, there were zero girls, and the one woman that was there was not from Hollywood and she guarded the front door with her life (I had a few empty bags from having dropped off my laundry at clothespin across the street on Lawrence and i think she thought i was going to loot up all the lingerie in my empty sacs.  I wasn't.  I did want to buy some long shiny boots and maybe a body stocking, but if there were actually sexy girls of the Hollywood there to assist me, i might have done so.  Luckily Modelo clubhouse is next door so I could cry in my "blue mother fucker" (third drink down on the menu - check my local photos) and eat a giant chili relleno with tortillas to calm the failed mission for sexy girls of the hollywood.  I may have to return for some boots.  But I still want to know where the girls are.

5.description: The name alone should turn people away but I gave it a try because I like to find cheap prices for ok things. I saw that they had "stripper shoes" which cost around 100 bucks at skyscrapper so I'm on a mission to find the highest heel at a better price. I walked in and immediately found a pair of mary jane knock offs and for only 30 bucks. When I went home and walked around for a moment to make sure they were dance floor ready I realized that they were beyond poorly made. I've been in heels since I was 7 so if I think they hurt I know they are worthless. I went to return them and get my money back and their policy is exchange only :| and I'm given a hard time because there's no way I want to "test" another pair of shoes. Well I ended up getting another pair as my  "work shoes" for clients and a parking ticket. Thanks but no thanks not coming back.

6.description: A very *interesting* selection of shoes, lingerie, dresses, and women's undergarments.  It's a cross between a Halloween costume shop, Fredrick's of Hollywood, and Discovery Clothing.  Do you need crotchless fishnet stockings?  They have it here.  How about stripper platform shoes?  Yep, they have those, too.  They also carry corsets, sexy Halloween costumes, and everything else in that category.  It's like Victoria's Secret with a sense of humor.

7.description: All the above post are complaining because they wanted to return something. I live in another state and go to Chicago for business I like this store. You get what you pay for the prices are good and the shoes are some of the same brands you find in the mall. I know because I have a store in a mall and I sell the same shoe's in my state. This store I think is very clever and right its not a victoria's secret but it also doesn't have the price tag either. Victoria's secret does returns but you pay an arm and a leg for a bra here for a 1/3 of the price you can get a cute set. If I am going to buy something from this store I would not take the time to go back and take it back for that bargan price. Ladies really shouldn't put negative things on a store because they didn't do a return. If you worked in retail you would also watch someone coming in with empty bags its the way things are now stop complaining and enjoy the great price and bargain. By the way I do think the customer service sucked but it was worth the cheap prices. You want to be treated like royality shop rodeo drive!

8.description: Sexy Girls is a cheap version of lovers lane meets chinatown.  This place has potential if the owners were not rip-off artists.  I went to return clothing the day after I bought it and they would not accept it.  I showed the lady how obvious it was I did not wear the item with tag still on but they refused to even EXCHANGE the item, going against their 10 day exchange policy.  She pulled the foreigner card and pretended not to understand me when  I would ask "are you the owner?" and she would only respond" yes I work here" this run around of Q and A went on for too long and was a waste of my time.  I left unhappy and with a chip on my shoulder.  Honestly would you risk buying an item with no guarantee that it could be returned and you could be refunded your money or exchange the item??? Not me, I know sometimes clothing or items look different once you are home..  To the Asian woman who pretended not to understand me and went against store policy I give you two thumbs down." I even read online that some other women had the same thing happen to them, this place is not worth the hassle.

0.description: Cheap sunglasses!Cheaper jewelry.Cheapest Lingerie.Seriously, the reviews expecting Nordstrom-levels-of-Supernatural service? Are you kidding? You are not kidding. Wowza. Really, this is a seriously cheap and slutty store for the girls who have grown out of or are now embarrassed to be seen in a Claire's Jewelry store. This IS like a dollar store, or a 7-11 of retail, with thongs. It is soooo cheap and cheesy, not really so much sexy as it is raunchy- which can be fun- if you aren't going in expecting to be worshiped like Carrie Bradshaw in a Prada store with an American Express Black Card.And you can buy cheap sunglasses- which is great, because I lose mine* everywhere!* (sunglasses, not underwear, get your dirty mind out of my reviews... there's the Admiral nearby for that.)

4.description: this is definitely not a store you take seriously. i'm not sure if it is a stripper store (given it's close proximity to the admiral) or a store for little girls, or a store for strippers AND their little girls. sexy shoes line the walls and cheap lingerie greets you when you walk in. this is a great place to get some stuff for halloween. in the back they have loads of cheap, plastic jewelry and hair accessories. most of it is 3 bucks or under. in the very back, they have a wall of leg warmers and leggings, some of which are super cute and pretty cheap. you would not buy much here expecting it to last a long time, but if you're looking for a costume or some cheap accessories for fun, this is the place to go.

58.description: I had a bit of a manic experience here today. I brought a groupon here and was met with confusion from the clerk.   Didn't exactly feel welcome, or was met with suggestions on what to buy. That said the sweets were fabulous. Very fresh.

56.description: We used to go to Nazareth, but ever since we tried Jaafer's sweets I don't think we will ever go anywhere else. We picked out a small sampler pack of various treats, and they were all delicious. They really pack in the high quality nuts, and there's a purity to the flavor of Jaafer's sweets that I can respect. Plus they are beautifully presented in the store, and the man behind the counter was very helpful when describing the differences. You can get the same sweets in other stores along this cooridor in Albany Park, but I think you will find the highest quality will be Jaafer's.

29.description: My sister wanted baklava for her birthday, so after a bit of research I settled on checking out Jaafer Sweets. I really liked the set up of the shop - colorful cookies and slices of baklava and other phyllo/nut/honey treats as well as colorful butter cookies stacked on serving stands. We bought some cookies and an assortment of baklava and another walnut/baklava type sweet. The cookies were just ok- they all kind of tasted the same. They looked better than they tasted. The baklava was just ok too- I think homemade baklava dripping with honey syrup is the best. Honestly, the best thing we tried was that walnut treat- I have no idea what it was called and I can't find it on the website. I would go back for that.

42.description: Picked up some Persian sweets for a party, they turned out great. Would buy from again.

23.description: Yum, so many Mid East style treats!!! Make sure to "Check-In" for a sweet deal!Most of the pastries are nutty and sweetened with honey.  The baklava has a light, flakey crust which is delicious.  I couldn't help myself and got an entire box.  There are a few tables to enjoy your desserts, but it is mainly a stop and go bakery. Will definitely return!

47.description: I went here after a vegan friend said they had vegan baklava, so I wanted to pick some up for a party. It took about 5 minutes to explain to the man behind the counter what I was talking about when I asked for vegan baklava. He kept thinking I meant for Passover.  They were delicious, however, the ingredients listed "vegetarian butter" so we were wondering if it really is vegan or not. I'm not vegan and she's not 100% militant about it, so she ate it anyway and it was fantastic. But I'd suggest trying to get clarification if you really do need to have vegan baklava, just in case.

8.description: I purchased several trays yesterday for myself and two family members. I drove to the city for the sole purpose of stopping here. The former owner sold the business to a man who was sitting at the counter at the window. When I was asking the woman behind the counter for specific items the man at the window would answer me, not her. A bit odd. But I presume he was the owner and the woman was his wife. (I later found out that that was true).Not too many options since the last time I was there. The stuff I did end up buying was not fresh. I'm very disappointed as I drove over an hour for the desserts I remembered being so delicious. I have two groupons that I can't use because she wouldn't let me use them on separate transactions or allow my mother who showed up later to use one of them. I'm for sure not driving back to the city just for this place. However,  the place was pretty clean. No complaints about that. I was more put off by the fact that the owner was too lazy to talk face to face with me but rather spoke to me while his back was to me. Nice. I was also not happy that I paid $45 (after using my one groupon) for stale desserts. Too bad, I used to love this place.

31.description: i have past this place many times since i moved to the neighborhood and i must say i am happy i decided to stop in. the baklava is simply the best i have ever tasted- no doubt there. the chocolate walnut baklava was out of this world. you just have to try for yourself. in addition my brother and i got some of their pastries which were different and unique. they were very good- my favorite is the cookies made from rice and the small marble sized doughnuts made from potato. i must add that i strolled in here around 11:45 pm- it is open late for ramadan till 12 midnight, then it will resume normal hours 10 pm. i met the husband and wife owners (who were the ones working) and they are just awesome! we literally tried 5 different treats before we settled on our order- compliment of the owners. this place is certainly a hidden gem that is not to be missed.

34.description: One of my Assyrian gf explained that Jaafer is the place to go for best middle eastern treats. How could I forget this gem?? Been here a long time ago with my world religion class and I still remember to this day how nice the owner and workers were. On this particular day, I stopped by to pick up a plethora of birthday goodies for my bf's father. He loves his baklava and I wanted to spoil him on this special day. We were instantly greeted by a sweet lady, who discussed the various types of party trays that I can assemble along with mixed assorted desserts baked daily every morning.** Sugary goodness I snagged ** :-Knafeh Kishna with side of liquid sugar-honey and crushed pistachios on top- assorted gift tray full of different baklava, pistachio birds nest,etc Store is clean & the aroma inside Jaafer Sweets hits up all your 5 senses to another dimension. Price is decent. I'd rather pay little more for well-made, quality desserts than a bland, fluffy cake from grocery stores. If you check in at Jaafer, they have an offer for 2 free desserts =] How can you beat that?!

16.description: Soo delicious!! Amazing quality desserts! Tried it for the first time, will definitely come back again. Staff super friendly!! Great gift for visiting friends or family!

13.description: Had mostly all types of baklava - mostly pretty good...Great service... and they do have vegan options (just in case)...Will try custard someday...

11.description: Yum, so many Mid East style treats!!! Make sure to "Check-In" for a sweet deal!Most of the pastries are nutty and sweetened with honey.  The baklava has a light, flakey crust which is delicious.  I couldn't help myself and got an entire box.  There are a few tables to enjoy your desserts, but it is mainly a stop and go bakery. Will definitely return!

39.description: Just great! I've had baklava and knafeh from here, and both were delicious. The decor and seating are pretty haphazard, but the sweets are topnotch and the owner is friendly. Free drinks are a nice touch too!

37.description: My mom learned of Jaafer Sweets from buying a package of baklava from Whole Foods. She figured why not go to the source? The location is about a block away from North Park University. Parking isn't bad.Hanna was working behind the counter and she was very helpful answering my mom's questions. A Yelp offer came up on my phone upon check-in as well. The quality and assortment was very good. Very sweet, maybe too sweet if you aren't familiar with Mediterranean sweets. I was missing the strong hit of butter and honey I typically associate with baklava but there was still plenty of flavor. The excellent service is what merits the most attention though. Good stuff here, I will return soon for more.

0.description: The Jaafer Sweets staff is incredibly friendly, and their baklava is to die for! I discovered Jaafer Sweets while planning an event for ALIVE Rescue Chicago, and since then I have craved their sweets every day : ) I am happy to give Jaafer Sweets 5 stars and would give them more if I could! I can't wait to try their baklava again in the near future!

38.description: They were really good just a little too sweet.

51.description: Jaafer Sweets is amazing! I first tried their baklava and ma'amoul at I Dream of Falafel on Franklin and loved it, so when it came time to cater an event, I knew this was the place to get our desserts from.Among all the pastries, Hanna is the sweetest thing there. She is welcoming, friendly, and extremely helpful. Given that I don't know of any other place around here that does Middle Eastern pastries and that these are such fantastic pastries, the price is justified (~$32 for a variety platter of 52 pastries).I really don't know the names of any of the pastries we had, so I can't give specifics, but there was not a single thing on the platter that wasn't delicious. Definitely going back!

27.description: I visited Jaafer for the first time today.  The first thing that I noticed was how attractive the shop is and how inviting the sweets look.  There was one woman working and she was super busy with someone who was ordering huge, multiple trays of sweets.  I spoke with the customer who was ordering the massive trays and she assured me these are the best.  When I finally got my turn I inquired about vegan sweets.  The woman not only pointed out the vegan varieties, but took the time to explain how they were made and what ingredients they used.  The time she took was greatly appreciated.  So, I walked out with a good sampler of vegan treats.  The highlight was the baklava made with walnuts.  It was gooey and flakey with a buttery (but not butter!) flavor.  I also had a taste of the sesame bar.  It wasn't too sweet but was packed with sesame seeds that had a nutty toasted flavor.  There was also a roll that reminded me of a shredded wheat biscuit, packed with walnuts.  It was rich and decadent.  So, even though sugar isn't the most healthful thing, I feel like these sweets redeemed themselves with nutritious ingredients like nuts and seeds.  Or, maybe I'm just justifying my next visit.

32.description: I LOVE THIS PLACE sooo much!!!! The owner is really nice and always around...The staff is very friendly....everything is just SO friggen yummy! AND ....(as im eating it in bed and giggling like a 5 year old).......They have Sugar-free Baklava!!  **HEAVEN!

54.description: Jaafer Sweets specializes in Middle Eastern sweets and pastries. The shop is in Albany Park. The product is superior to that of a major neighboring bakery, but it is still not that good.I purchased a tray of assorted baklava type Middle Eastern pastries. Having tasted one of each of the six types of pastry, I find all of them to be so-so in flavor. The ingredients need an upgrade. The pastries themselves are well put together: good handling of the pastry dough.These are two of the ingredients that are absent from Jaafer's baklava: butter and honey. There might be others, but these two are pretty fundamental components to standard baklava. The overall effect of their absence creates a flavor-dead filo dough drenched in sugar syrup.Perhaps there are no bakeries in Chicago that produce genuine baklava. Jaafer does not. However, Jaafer's product is superior to that of a major, well-known bakery down the street.In short, Jaafer Sweets is a disappointment.10-2-11 (update)Having read the other reviews, I should let Yelpers know that I have a high regard for the hospitality of the shop owners and workers that I met during my visit. The woman was welcoming and extremely enthusiastic. She was also genuinely interested in getting feedback regarding Jaafer's product. The man offered us both a complimentary drink. We had to decline because we were in a hurry, so I'm not sure what it was he was offering to us.My experience with Jaafer was entirely consistent with meeting small business owners, ones who are actually running the business and greeting customers. To me, they seemed genuinely interested in growing their business and working with customers. I don't know if this is entirely "good service", but it is good business practice, and their attitude was genuinely hospitable. The hospitality component might be cultural, something that is more Middle Eastern.Chalk me up on the plus side of the service evaluation of Jaafer Sweets by Yelpers.'--wys

48.description: We found this gem through Groupon and tried it out a few weeks ago. I have had a fair number of Middle Eastern sweets in my day, but this is definitely the best I've ever  had! They have a wide variety to choose from, and everything is absolutely delicious. We made a customized assortment, and the server at the shop was incredibly friendly and helpful in picking out sweets. He even gave us free samples and tea while we were deciding what to get. It was super fast, and I really can't say enough nice things about the service. I don't typically go back to the same place twice, but I'll make an exception for this place. Try it! :)

44.description: Excellent sweets, and the owner/or attendant is very nice!

24.description: I'd give it a 4.5 stars. Nice place and great selection of Mediterrean/Arabic treats. Yummy:)

7.description: I wrote a review on April 17 but it's not showing up.  I think it's because I referenced something that I shouldn't have.  So I will edit and remove that portion.  Hopefully, my review won't be deleted.We were ripped off!  We came here after dinner at the restaurant next door last night.  It was about 8:35 pm and there was no one at the front.  Finally a guy came from the back and asked what we wanted.We asked what do most people order because we had never been there before.  I said I love pistachio, so what's a good pistachio item.  He pointed to the top row which had ballourie, baklava, and pistachio ring.We picked the ballourie from his recommendations.  It was literally only 1 inch x 1 inch.  TINY but we just wanted to satisfy our sweet toothes.  He walked over to the cashier and rang it up ... $1.99 EACH ... for a 1 inch x 1 inch piece of ballourie.We had already eaten it because it was so tiny, so we reluctantly just paid and left.We were clearly overcharged because the cashier knew we were not regular customers.So my WARNING to fellow yelpers, is that you should not go to this place.  They will rip you off.  Such a dishonest stunt of cheating customers should not be tolerated.Thanks for letting me have "someone" to complain to.

49.description: Short and sweet. Solid experience, nice and fast. Nice decor, excellent pastries

40.description: authentic baklava with all kinds of fillings! friendly staff! you get a sample just for checking in here!

53.description: Only one vegan option, but it is FANTASTIC.  Many vegans miss baklava, as it has honey and often butter as well.  It's always at the felafel shops just staring back.  Well fret no longer friends, because Jaafer is here to help, and how!Super buttery (almost to a suspicious degree), chewy, and moist.  And you do not have to special order it, it's just there.  So much better than any baklava I have ever had.It may look unassuming from the strip-mall parking lot, but it's warm and friendly inside.  Staff was super nice and expedient.I am told more vegan options are on the way.  They even catered a vegan wedding.Definitely worth a trip out here, no matter where in the city you live.

30.description: I love their vegan baklava, you can't even taste the difference

46.description: I took advantage of the $5 for $10 deal during Yelp's Sugar Week promotion.Jaafer sweets was definitely as good as I've heard! My cohort and I got an assortment of delicious different types of baklava and treats. I had eaten normal baklava before, but it was really interesting being able to directly compare different types to one another--you can really taste the difference in texture and flavor.Even at regular prices, it was a pretty good amount of sweets for the value. Dropping $10-$20 here before a potluck would make you a very popular person. If you've never tried arab sweets before, I highly recommend stopping in here and just trying one of everything they have. They also have cookies and this one snack that I would describe as a sesame seed rice krispy. Great stuff.The customer service was also great, the people there seemed very nice.My only gripe, like others have mentioned, was that the store was hot as hell. It's not a huge deal but it would be nice to sit down in there and eating during summer.

1.description: Sorry but I did not like this place. I honestly believe the reviews are highly overrated.. The customer service was lame. The employee wasn't very helpful with the questions. I have also received hate mail after reviewing this location negatively. The sweets are okay as well.. nothing exceptional. I am hoping to try a different place next time, since this is definitely not the place for me.==============Update 9/2  As you can see I received an unapologetic response on this  review from the store. According to them I must like cheap not so good tasting sweets and that's why I didn't like their store. As you can tell, even the store owners are not very friendly and customer oriented. Read the reviews and you'll notice how many people have complained about lack of customer service.================Update 11/6I have received another hate email from a user for giving this place a negative review. This is really sad. I gave a negative review based on my experience. But I guess for some people that's too much to handle.=====================Update 1/11/2016Received another email from the owner. These people are extremely unprofessional. Here is the email message. "I want you to prove the hate mail you have been receiving from us, If you don't like shopping with us, then STOP reviewing us, Go to Michigan and shop there,"As you can see the store owners are not customer oriented and all of this is over a negative review. I had a bad experience with the business and I wrote a review that I believe reflects my experience. This is exactly what Yelp is about.

55.description: The kinafa here has brought me to tears on occasion, especially when they are sold out.  The other night, i really wanted this dessert called "Jiban- something or another", in English it is called "Cheese Delights."  I used to get it in the South Suburbs at a Syrian Bakery in Bridgeview, but they went out of business.  Needless to say, when I mentioned this sweet, the owner said he had it!  It's not exactly the same as the Syrian one, but the taste is close.  Jaffar makes it with kinafa dough on the outside, the Syrian one is cheese dough with cream inside, making it a bit more delicate and complicated texture when you take a bite.  If you try it, do not forget the syrup on the side to dip it in.If you use Yelp, and sign up for email alerts, you get free baklava and a free beverage!So Tayip!  Shukran!!

9.description: Best baklava in Chicago! Many varieties to choose from including pistachio or cashew, but the chocolate walnut is my favorite hands-down! Great texture and just the right amount of honey. Always pleasant service and my Yelp check-in garnered me two free pieces!

26.description: I've tried a fair share of baklava but Jaafar Sweets is on top. The shop is located on a small strip on Kedzie, the place is very neat and well presented. They sell the trays (small, medium, large) but charge you depending on the weight. We mix and matched getting some cookies, fried dough and of course the different flavors of baklava. The sweets tasted very fresh and well worth it. Not recommended to sit and eat, there are a couple of fold-chairs. Overall great place to go for some Mediterranean treats!!

25.description: I came in here after eating at a cafe next door and I haven't had baklava in a long time, nor did I know that there were so many different flavors and shapes. I came in based on the 2 free baklava they offer from checking in on yelp. I asked the lady about the different dessert and she kinda just distracted me to the prepackaged stuff. Not knowing how much I would like everything, I didn't want to spend $17 and up on a box of unknowns. So I pointed and asked about a couple in the case and asked for one of each, and she kinda rolled her eyes like I was wasting her time. Then I showed her my two free baklava offer and she rolled her eyes again and made a comment that they don't have bags for such a small order. I just wanted to try these desserts and possibly come back later to purchase more next time. But I left that place feeling uncomfortable and awkward. Like maybe this place isn't the right place for me. When I got home I tried each of the different desserts that I brought back and they all tastes the same. I can respect the amount of work that goes into making these but the fillings were all so dense and sweet it's a little too much for me. The phyllo had a nice flaky crunch but when I bit into the filling it was chewy and stuck to my teeth. I don't know if this is how baklava are meant to be, but I feel that I would have enjoyed it more if the filling was lighter in texture and flavor. Whether I liked it or not, I wouldn't return based off of the rudeness of the worker. You don't have to smile to give good service, but it helps. And making your customers feel like they're wasting your time is not a way to get repeat business. Based on the other reviews here maybe It's just me, and everyone else can appreciate the quality of desserts here.

12.description: The baklava was good. However, it is just as good as the place across the street "Nazareth Sweets". The reason why i give this review 2 stars is because of the price. I feel as though I got ripped off. I got a medium tray of baklava, for initially $42 dollars, after a discount it was $30 dollars. The people across the street will give you baklava just as good (maybe better) and just as much for HALF THE PRICE! ($15). I feel as though this place is just a much more expensive version of other baklava bakeries.  I feel as though I got cheated by this place.

59.description: Umm, awesome!It's a bit of a hike from UChicago but it was well worth it. Bought a Groupon and used  it to bring home a giant tray full of delicious sweets. I don't know what half of them are called but the chocolate walnut was excellent...hell, all of them were excellent. The girl who helped us was very helpful and helped me pick out a great assortment of all the different sweets they had to offer. I will definitely be back!

21.description: This is a great bakery. We came here based off yelp reviews. We opened the door to the sound of wind chimes, a nice sound, and the beauty of the treats immediately had me saying, "This is sacred ground." The older guy was super nice, I had asked him how do we go about ordering since it was our first time. Pick whatever, he puts it in the tray, and its paid for by the pound. We bought two pounds of assorted treats and I'll be damned if it wasn't amazing.A fine example is that we hate coconut. Not the thing itself, but everything that claims to taste like it or is made out of it. One of the treats was made from coconut, to which we dismissed, but he offered us a free sample saying how people usually don't like coconut.No wonder he had us try it while reinforcing how we felt, cause he beat back how we felt about the treat. We loved it, considering how much we don't care for coconut. It's cheap, its quality, and we will be going back there again easily.

17.description: Walked into this place thinking it was the same place I had come to know growing up. I was wrong:-(  ordered a tray of Kenafe and was told over half a dozen times by the driver that if I knew I wanted Kenafe I should have ordered it in advance. Was told it would take 10 minutes to prepare and almost 25 min later it was finally ready. I asked them not to add pistachios on top of it but to give me a little on the side because although my daughter is allergic to nuts my mom likes a little on top of her kenafe. The driver proceeded to tell me how we can't please everyone and about a second later who I could only assume may have been the baker came out and said they don't give pistachio on the side in a very snippy way. Almost $45 and 25 minutes later that's the least they could have done. No worries, I won't be back again, so you can save your pistachios since I ended up throwing away almost the entire Kenafe.

10.description: Last time when I got bamya person who was helping was actually picking the old ones it was like a rock and I bought 6 had to throw in the garbage 4 of them I think they prefer loosing customers  instead of loosing few peace of desert good luck

5.description: The baklava here is delicious!  They make a variety of flavors, but the pistachio and walnut ones are my favorite.  The lady behind the counter was so helpful in making recommendations especially since we weren't as familiar with the other types of desserts they offer.  We went ahead and bought a small tray of assorted baklava and pastries.  You can check in on Yelp and get a few pieces of walnut baklava for free, I think it's 4.

3.description: Yum! Tried a variety of sweets. One that surprised us (in a good way) was the cranberry chocolate - it was more tart than sweet. Would definitely grab that one again. Overall, a great bakery, and being inexpensive doesn't hurt.

35.description: We were in the area for grocery and meat shopping and decided to stop by this place to fulfill our sweet tooth. This place is very clean and has a lot of different Middle-Eastern sweets. We didn't buy much but the stuff we did buy, was really delicious. Some of the sweets they make only for occasions, like for Ramadan. All the sweets are made on the spot in the back and we got the fresh batch for our sweets. It seems as though this place does a lot of catering. Quite delicious and the price wasn't too pricey. Definitely a great place for fresh home-made style sweets.

19.description: Really friendly helpful owner, very tasty cashew baklava that we got for free with yelps check in offer, and overall very tasty middle eastern sweets. Definitely authentic arabic desserts. They also sell desserts at whole foods and marianos, so I'll definitely be purchasing more baklava from here. They also have chocolate baklava which looks fantastic! Go figure!

28.description: I once saw an episode of "Bizarre Foods," where Zimmern went to Dearborn, MI. and spent some time in local bakeries.  In one he tried "Knafeh," a sweet cheese baked with a sugar glaze on top.  Since seeing that episode, I've wondered where in the sam hell I could find that delicious treat.Enter Jaafer Sweets, a small Middle Eastern bakery located in a strip mall on Kedzie directly across the street from Nazareth.  There are a TON of bakeries in this area, but I picked Jaafer since several reviews highlighted the Knafeh.They also sell a wide variety of cookies, baklava, and loads of other things I couldn't pronounce.  Cookies are sold by the pound, at $9.99.  I also scored an awesome check-in deal on Yelp for 2 free pieces of baklava.I've never had baklava before, but the walnut baklava was very good.  The pastry was a little flaky, and the filling had a chewiness that reminded me of toffee.The Knafeh takes 10 minutes to bake, so be sure you have the time to wait.  We both had a few bites before we continued on our way, and it is definitely an interesting treat worth trying AND it is big enough to feed 2-4 people.  We barely made a dent in it.I was a little thrown off when we walked in, and two men working in the back were listening to Mexican Mariachi style music.  I expected this bakery to be a family-run kind of place.  I didn't think much of it until the man behind the counter wasn't able to explain to me what any of the pastries were.  I asked him about the "baked cheese with pistachios" since I could not recall "Knafeh," and I didn't understand a word he said to me other than when he showed me the pan and said, "$9.99."  Despite the language barrier, he was very nice to us and patient while we decided.There is only one table with two chairs in here, but we were lucky that other customers took their orders to go.  I'd sort of intended for us to split a few pastries, but aside from the Knafeh, most of the cookies were 1-2 bites big and not ideal for sharing.  The cookies all looked really good and would make a great treat for your office, holiday party, or birthday.They also sell vegan and sugar-free baklava.  I would go back for the baklava for sure.  I would have liked for the menus to be more descriptive, including the random labels on the glass, because I probably would have purchased a sack of cookies.

45.description: Love this place... the staff is very friendly and the sweets are super good and taste just the same as they do back home, even better! and most importantly the place is always clean.. which tells you a lot about the people who works there!! over all my favorite sweet place in town! :D

33.description: Jaafer is an institution in this part of the city and for quite a good reason..their sweets are incredible! Jaafer is my go to for a great selection baklava while in AP. I've stopped in here a few times when it is my turn to bring in treats to work or I feel like surprising my colleagues. Their selection of baklava is incredibly extensive and you can either get the prepackaged trays or make your own if there is something that you really like.  I don't stop in here regularly for myself as their treats are addictive. I doubt a tray would last 2 days in my house as it is typically gone in 15 minutes when I bring it to work.

43.description: Incredible smells and baklava

2.description: Holy smokes. SUPER DELICIOUS!!! I'm not a baklava expert by any means but I've had my share of them at different locations. I was in the area when I felt like I needed something sweet. Luckily, this place was close by. They charge by weight so I picked a few in a mini-tray (can hold up to 8, maybe 10, little treats). My favorite was the walnut baklava which was complete heaven in my mouth. The baklava itself is not terribly sweet but the honey infused really brings out the flavor. For those with a bigger sweet tooth, the chocolate walnut is delicious too! The baklava with cashew was close to being on par with the walnut. Also a big plus is that there's a parking lot right in front of the store.Anyway, I've found another reason why I love being in Chicago!! The best baklava!

18.description: Konafa kishna = sweet cheese. Konafa kishta= sweet cream. We tried the kishta- it was delicious. Tastes just like the way my mom makes it. Three sizes, the smallest tray was 11.99 and definitely worth it. It took exactly 9 minutes to have it ready. They offer extra syrup on the side. Make sure you take it because you will need it when you reheat any leftovers in the oven. But you won't need any extra syrup when it's fresh because they pour the syrup right before they give it to you. When you reheat at home the next day or two (don't use the microwave because that dries it out), immediately AFTER taking it out, poor some of the extra syrup over the top. It will absorb the syrup while hot. If you pour it BEFORE you heat it, the syrup will stay on the top and then will carmelize in the oven.

41.description: I walked into this place and it smelled SO GOOD.  Absolutely everything we tried was delicious.  I had pistachio, cashews, almonds, chocolate and walnut...mmm...I'm getting hungry again thinking about it!The owner also gave me and my friend each a free drink! They were really nice.  Definitely come here.

52.description: I found out that Jaafer Sweets uses an ingrediant called Maltitol in their sugar free baklava. Many companies use this to be able to say that their products are sugar free. Diabetics have to be careful since Malitol is not like splenda and has more than 75% of the carbs of regular sugar.

50.description: Had the vegan baklava and it was great! Growing up on non-vegan baklava I was worried it just wouldn't be the same, however it was freakishly close! The first one I ate I did notice a slight difference, perhaps maybe not as sweet as the non-vegan version. However, I ate one more and I was totally adjusted to the very slight difference and thoroughly enjoyed it. Had to put the box away for fear I'd eat too many!!!

4.description: Expensive and the staff is not nice at all. Yeah if you need a baklava fix this is the place, but very mediocre. Will not be coming back

6.description: We recently came here with some friends that we were visiting in the Chicago area.  We were eating in the cafe next door and noticed the high Yelp ratings so decided to stop by afterwards since my wife loves baklava.  We did not feel welcome at all in the store from the moment we walked in.  And that discomfort grew when we asked to buy just 2 pieces since we were all stuffed from dinner and then used the Yelp check-in to get an additional 2 pieces.The baklava itself was good and we probably would have gone back again the next day to get some more had we not had such a negative customer service experience.

22.description: The best baklava my wife and I have ever had (and lots of other great sweets too) -- we've shared it all over town and even shipped it to relatives and everyone agrees it's as good as it gets.  The owner is very knowledgeable about all the items and incredibly courteous and attentive whenever we come in: it's always a pleasure to shop here.

15.description: I once saw an episode of "Bizarre Foods," where Zimmern went to Dearborn, MI. and spent some time in local bakeries.  In one he tried "Knafeh," a sweet cheese baked with a sugar glaze on top.  Since seeing that episode, I've wondered where in the sam hell I could find that delicious treat.Enter Jaafer Sweets, a small Middle Eastern bakery located in a strip mall on Kedzie directly across the street from Nazareth.  There are a TON of bakeries in this area, but I picked Jaafer since several reviews highlighted the Knafeh.They also sell a wide variety of cookies, baklava, and loads of other things I couldn't pronounce.  Cookies are sold by the pound, at $9.99.  I also scored an awesome check-in deal on Yelp for 2 free pieces of baklava.I've never had baklava before, but the walnut baklava was very good.  The pastry was a little flaky, and the filling had a chewiness that reminded me of toffee.The Knafeh takes 10 minutes to bake, so be sure you have the time to wait.  We both had a few bites before we continued on our way, and it is definitely an interesting treat worth trying AND it is big enough to feed 2-4 people.  We barely made a dent in it.I was a little thrown off when we walked in, and two men working in the back were listening to Mexican Mariachi style music.  I expected this bakery to be a family-run kind of place.  I didn't think much of it until the man behind the counter wasn't able to explain to me what any of the pastries were.  I asked him about the "baked cheese with pistachios" since I could not recall "Knafeh," and I didn't understand
